## geom_histogram{#histogram}

```{r, echo=FALSE}
worldbankdata |>
  filter(Year == 2021) |>
ggplot(aes(x = Cooking)) + 
  geom_histogram(col="white")

```

## geom_hline{#hline}


**Package: ** ggplot2 [@R-ggplot2]

**Book: **

**Description: ** Draw a horizontal line ($Y=c$) for a given value of $c$, which is known as `yintercept`.

**Understandable aesthetics:** alpha, colour, linetype, linewidth

**Statistics layer(s):**

**See also: ** [geom_point](#point), [geom_vline](#vline), [geom_hline](#hline)

**Example:**

```{r, fig.cap="Illustration of (A) geom_hline and (B) use of geom_point and geom_hline both"}
hline <- ggplot(worldbankdata, aes(y = Cooking, x= Electricity)) + geom_hline(yintercept = 50) + 
  labs(title="A: `geom_hline` only") +
  theme(aspect.ratio = 1)

pointhline <- ggplot(worldbankdata, aes(y = Cooking, x=Electricity)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 50) + 
  labs(title="B: `geom_point + geom_hline` both") +
  theme(aspect.ratio = 1)


hline | pointhline
```
